assumption: AlphaFold models assume that static structure prediction is sufficient for understanding protein function
hypothesis: Incorporating folding dynamics and intermediate states into prediction models will significantly improve accuracy for multi-domain and allosteric proteins
impact: Could revolutionize drug design by predicting conformational changes and binding site accessibility

assumption: More training data always leads to better protein structure prediction models
hypothesis: Strategically limited training data focusing on essential folding principles will outperform large-scale models for novel protein families
impact: Would enable structure prediction for completely new protein classes with minimal homology

assumption: Protein sequences uniquely determine their structures (one-sequence-one-structure paradigm)
hypothesis: Multiple distinct folding pathways can achieve equivalent functions, requiring ensemble-based prediction approaches
impact: Could explain protein evolution and enable design of proteins with switchable functions

assumption: Thermodynamic stability is the primary driver of protein folding and should guide prediction models
hypothesis: Kinetic folding pathways and co-translational folding provide better prediction frameworks than thermodynamic approaches
impact: Would transform understanding of protein misfolding diseases and in vivo protein behavior

assumption: AlphaFold's architecture limitations with topology (knots, links, membrane proteins) are inherent to deep learning approaches
hypothesis: Topology-aware neural network architectures with geometric constraints can overcome these limitations
impact: Would expand structure prediction to membrane proteins and knotted proteins, unlocking new therapeutic targets

assumption: Sequence-structure relationship learning requires massive evolutionary data (MSA depth)
hypothesis: Physics-informed neural networks can achieve comparable accuracy with minimal evolutionary information by encoding folding physics
impact: Could enable structure prediction for synthetic proteins and de novo designed sequences
